posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
As the title says, we are looking for options to support our (future) new CNC Router. We will likely be getting a 48”x48” Router. Theoverall size will be closer to 52”x52” once you add space for external cable drapes etc.

So the question is, how do you, or would you, support this machine?

Pre-built table? Custom built table? 8020 frame? Mobile or stationary? The list goes on, but you get the idea.

We want to plan ahead so we are ready once it delivers.

Pictures and plans, or links to them,  would be awesome as well!

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: We use a sturdy shop made wood table. You want something that is not shake when the head moves around

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked: It all depends on what your team wants. Putting it on a table would be cheap, but could be annoying. You could make a stand, but there is no guarantee that it would be stable. You could buy a stand, but those are fairly expensive. Weigh the pros and cons of each and pick what serves your purposes best.

posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: I’ll try and get a picture, but we’ve got the most insanely overengineered stack of 2x4s bolted into the concrete floor
Buy a Sienci 4x4 Altmill (or 4x8 when it is released in a month or two) - it comes with legs.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: Love it. Yes, pictures please.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Here is what I learn. Recently got 4X4 SO5.

Put them on casters so you can move it around. Choose Caster that you can lowered the pad to the ground so your table doesn’t move around.

More mass on the bottom of the table. Use the space on the bottom for storing things. This helps to dampen the inertia of the high feed.

Height. Too high, it would be hard to reach for 4X4. Full access to all sides is better.

Flat table. The flatter the better. Your CNC will sit on top of it.

This table is overkilled, made it out of welded square tubes and 2” table top (AdvanTech OSB, which denser and heavier duty), but I love it.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
Do you have a center leg support in the middle to prevent deflection under heavier Z loads? I have heard that can be an issue with the SO5. Or, is the OSB sufficient?

BTW, nice setup!

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked: I thought about that, but so far I didn’t see any evidence of it. The Table frame has cross members but not a center leg. The 2 AdvanTech OSB ply is also super rigid and helps transfer the load to the steel frame. So far we’re super happy with it.

posts.name: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826
posts.cooked: We got the prebuilt stand for our Shop Sabre 23.  It is rock solid and I think helps the overall excellence of the work.  Cripes, today our design lead cut a flywheel out of half inch aluminum!  So don’t go cheap on this.  OTOH, we are making an enclosure out of pvc pipe and clear tarp with basic “shower curtain” design.  Things that don’t touch the machine are less critical.
posts.display_username: tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826

posts.cooked: Do you have one of the AltMill routers? We’re leaning towards getting one but since it’s so new we can’t really find information about how it’s been for people, so if you have one and can describe your experiences that would be great.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
I think the correct term is RIGIDITY!

Next question, open to all. Do you use a Mist Cooler/Lubricator, and if so, what brand and/or model?

posts.cooked: We are just in the process of putting ours together so we don’t have any experience using it.  We bought it based upon all the comparisons of it vs the other Prosumer CNC’s.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked: For Aluminum? We never used one. We ran dry with Air Blast + Single Flute Up Cut cutter.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
Thanks, input like this always helps.

We have used a Stepcraft D800 for a year now, and frankly, it just isn’t up to the task of cutting aluminum. It’s fine for poly and we are keeping it for that but adding the PwnCNC Dominator for all large size and metal jobs.

posts.name: Devin Castellucci
posts.cooked: Mist is best. 1678 always buys the cheap amazon ones and gets a precision flow control valve from McMaster. I’ve posted a few times about it on CD but let me know  if you can’t find the details and I’ll dig it up for you.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: I followed this one. It basicly lead me to everything I needed to know on the subject, but was afraid to ask. Seriously, a blow torch on IPA mist? Bahahahaha!
